Long-cycling lithium-oxygen batteries enabled by tailoring Li nucleation and deposition via lithiophilic oxygen vacancy in Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x composite anodes Yu Yan Chaozhu Shu ⁎ Ruixin Zheng Minglu Li Zhiqun Ran Miao He Longfei Ren Dayue Du Ying Zeng ⁎ College of Materials and Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Chengdu University of Technology, Chengdu 610059, Sichuan, China College of Materials and Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Chengdu University of Technology Chengdu 610059 Sichuan China College of Materials and Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Chengdu University of Technology, Chengdu 610059, Sichuan, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Vo-TiO2/Ti3 C2Tx scaffold with excellent lithiophilicity can decrease Li heterogeneous nucleation barrier on the scaffold, which modulates uniform Li nucleation behavior and subsequent Li deposition. Uncontrollable Li dendrite growth and infinite volume fluctuation during durative plating and stripping process gravely hinder the application of metallic Li electrode in lithium-oxygen batteries. Herein, oxygen vacancy-rich TiO2 (Vo-TiO2) nanoparticles (NPs) uniformly dispersing on Ti3C2T x (Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x ) with excellent lithiophilicity feature are presented as effective composite anodes, on which a dense and uniform Li growth behavior is observed. Based on electrochemical studies, mutiphysics simulation and theoretical calculation, it is found that Vo-TiO2 coupling with three dimensional (3D) conductive Ti3C2T x MXene forms highly ordered lithiophilic sites which succeed in guiding Li ions flux and adsorption, thus modulating the uniform Li nucleation and growth. As a result, this composite electrode is capable of preserving Li with high areal capacity of ~10 mAh cm−2 without the presence of dendrites and large volume expansion. Consequently, the as-prepared Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode shows outstanding performance including low voltage hysteresis (~19 mV) and superior durability (over 750 h). When assembling with the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes, lithium-oxygen batteries also deliver enhanced cycling stability and improved rate performance. This work demonstrates the effectiveness of oxygen vacancies in guiding Li nucleating and plating behavior at initial stage and brings a promising strategy for promoting the development of advanced Li metal-based batteries. Keywords Lithium-oxygen batteries Electrode materials Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x composite Oxygen vacancies Adsorption energy 1 Introduction Technological progress of grid-scale energy storage, electrical transportation, as well as portable electronic devices are closely accompanied with the development of advanced rechargeable batteries [1,2]. Although batteries, especially Li ion batteries (LIBs), have achieved tremendous success in commercial applications, they are still constrained by limited energy density and poor durability [3,4]. In such a context, Li metal batteries such as lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries with metallic Li anodes, have aroused great attention due to their overwhelming high theoretical energy density [5–9]. As the critical component of Li metal batteries, Li metal anode possesses high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1), low potential (−3.04 V vs. RHE), and low density (0.534 g cm−3) [10–13]. However, Li metal anode suffers several formidable challenges including dendrite formation resulting from nonuniform Li deposition and the infinite volume expansion at the current stage [14,15], causing potential safety concerns and unsatisfied Coulombic efficiency [12]. For decades, several approaches such as electrolyte additives [16–20], artificial protective layers [21–23], solid state electrolyte [24–26], and high concentration electrolyte [27,28], have been adopted to circumvent these unfavorable issues. Previous studies found that current density plays a critical role in the Li nucleation and deposition behavior. Severe Li dendrite formation and growth caused by high local current density is the main issue which needs to be overcome urgently for Li metal anode before the practical application. It is found that the formation of Li dendrites can be significantly inhabited at a relatively low current density [29]. Moreover, uncontrolled spatial expansion during Li deposition at high capacity remains a serious challenge for the traditional hostless Li electrodes. Recently, three-dimensional (3D) conductive scaffolds have been found to be able to reduce the local current density when accommodating Li deposits, according to the sand’s formula [30]. Apart from that, various hosts provide free space for pre-storage of Li metal, enabling to effectively reduce the volume change during Li plating and stripping behaviors [31–34]. MXenes, generally denoted as M n +1X n T x , where M is early transition metal, X represents carbon and/or nitrogen, and T x is the terminated functional groups such as –O, –OH and –F, have been widely employed in energy storage, sensors, water purification and catalysis [35]. Recently, decorated MXenes as metallic Li anode current collectors demonstrate outstanding performances due to their low Li+ diffusion barrier, good electronic conductivity and superior mechanical properties [36]. However, at high current density, uneven mass transfer and Li+ flux distribution on the MXene current collectors generally bring about inhomogeneous Li nucleation thus leading to ultra-low utilization of electroactive region inside the host. In addition, the subsequent Li deposition largely depends on the initial nuclei which are crucial but still elusive. Therefore, it’s reasonable to regulate active sites with low nucleation overpotential in the early nucleating stage. To this end, developing a suitable strategy to regulate homogeneous Li+ flux and distribution on the surface of 3D MXenes and manipulate the initial Li nuclei is believed to be favorable for the dendrite-free Li deposition. In consideration of that the introduction of heterostructures and the intrinsic defects in 2D materials can cause some interesting transformations in electrical, magnetic, mechanical, thermal and chemical properties, they can be introduced into 3D MXenes for designing promising Li host [36,37]. In this work, we propose highly dispersed oxygen vacancy-rich TiO2 NPs acting as lithiophilic nucleation sites on 3D conductive Ti3C2T x scaffold (Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x ) synthesized via one-step ethanol-thermal treatment of the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets. The influence of electric-field distribution and lithiophilic nature of the scaffold on Li nucleation and deposition are studied via COMSOL multiphysics simulation and DFT calculations in detail. The combination of uniform lithiophilic sites and large specific surface area along with optimized porous framework of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x can not only provide “seed points” and diffusion channels, but also function as “buffer layer” to alleviate volume change and relieve local current density to a great extent. Based on above merits, low nucleation overpotential of 17 mV is realized at 0.2 mA cm−2, which is much lower than previously reported counterparts. Remarkably, Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x based symmetrical cells exhibit a low voltage hysteresis of ~19 mV over 750 h. In addition, when employing the as-prepared Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes, Li-O2 full batteries also demonstrate improved energy efficiency and durability. By deepening the study on the initial nucleation behavior on the lithiophilic nucleation sites, our research offers an efficient approach to develop safe and stable Li metal batteries. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Titanium aluminum carbide (Ti3AlC2) MAX powders (98%, 200 meshes) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ethanol (99%, AR), hydrofluoric acid (HF) (40%, GR), N-Methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) (99%, AR), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) (hsv900), 1 M LiTFSI/DOL-DME (1/1, V/V) with 1 wt.% LiNO3 and 1 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolytes were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Lithium metal foils were purchased from China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd. Celgard 2400 polypropylene (PP) and glass fiber (Whatman, GF/D) membranes were purchased from Shenzhen Kejing Star Technology Co., Ltd. Nickel foams were purchased from Shanghai Hesen Electric Company. 2.2 Preparation of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold To prepare Ti3C2T x nanosheets, Ti3AlC2 MAX powders were immersed in 40% HF solution for 12 h. Then the obtained product was washed by deionized water until the pH reaching 5–6. Ti3C2T x MXene powders were obtained via freeze-drying method. To prepare Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , 0.5 g Ti3C2T x powders were added into 50 ml ethanol and followed by solvothermal treatment (140 °C, 12 h). The Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x was obtained by freeze drying the suspension. The 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffolds were prepared by coating slurry (1.26 g Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x and 0.14 g PVDF dispersed in NMP solution) on Cu foil (9 μm) and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The material load on the Cu foil is 1 mg cm−2. The 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold was then cut into electrodes with diameter of 1.6 cm. 2.3 Material characterization Crystal structure and composition of samples were characterized via X-ray diffraction (XRD, Japan, D/MAX-IIIC). Morphology and structure were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Japan, JSM-6700F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Japan, JEOL 2100F). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on ESZALB 250XL to characterize the surface elements of the samples. The specific surface area (SSA) was measured using nitrogen adsorption analyzer (Micrometrics, Model ASAP 2460). The correlation coefficients for Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x and Ti3C2T x were 0.9969405 and 0.9947408, respectively. ESR spectrometer (Bruker, EMXmicro-6/1/P/L) was used to study the vacancy. 2.4 Preparation of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode The 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold was assembled into CR2032 coin cells with Celgard-2400 separator and 1 M LiTFSI/DOL-DME (1/1, V/V) with 1 wt.% LiNO3, ~30 μL) electrolyte in argon-filled glove box. Before Li electroplating and further electrochemical measurements, an activation process was conducted. In detail, symmetric cells were first cycled between 0 and 1 V (vs. Li+/Li) at a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2 for 4 cycles to remove impurities and form stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI). A constant current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 was then applied to electrodeposit metallic Li into the 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x to produce the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li. 2.5 Electrochemical measurement Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li based coin cells were assembled with Celgard-2400 separator and 1 M LiTFSI/DOL-DME (1/1, V/V) with 1 wt.% LiNO3 electrolyte (~30 μL) in argon-filled glove box. For the control samples, pure Ti3C2T x , TiO2 and bare Cu foil were employed to replace the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , making symmetric cells with the other conditions to be the same. A certain amount of Li was deposited onto the current collectors and then charged to 1.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) to strip the Li for each cycle, during which the Coulombic efficiency were calculated. Nucleation overpotential is defined as the voltage difference between the sharp tip voltage and the following stable mass transfer-controlled overpotential. To evaluate the cycling stability, 2 mAh cm−2 Li was first pre-deposited on the current collectors at 0.5 mA cm−2. After that, 0.1 mAh cm−2 Li was stripped from the deposited lithium and then plated to Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li or Cu@Li electrodes at 0.1 mA cm−2. Besides, relatively large capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 Li was stripped from the deposited lithium and then plated to Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li electrode or Cu@Li electrodes at 1 mA cm−2. Li-O2 batteries were also assembled in the argon-filled glove box by employing Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li as anode, glass fiber as the separator, 1 M LiTFSI in TEGDME as electrolyte, and Super P as cathode. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) test was conducted on CHI 600E electrochemical workstation at open circuit voltage with a voltage amplitude of 5 mV at a frequency range from 1000 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Galvanostatic discharge/charge measurement was carried out on the LAND CT2001A battery test system. 2.6 Modeling and simulations Density functional theory calculation has been employed to describe the molecular adsorption in tetranuclear complex with pseudopotential by the projector-augmented wave (PAW) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE). In addition, the cut-off energy has been set to 400 eV and the Brillouin zone has been used with a 3 × 3 × 1Γ-centered k-mesh for our cell simplified. All structures were optimized until the self-consistent force is less than 0.03 eV Å−1 and the energy between two consecutive steps was less than 10-6 eV. In our calculation, the adsorption energy is calculated by using the equation: E f = E total- EV total-E 1, where the E total is the surface or interface structure with adsorbed lithium, and EV total is the energy of the surface or interface structure, E 1 is the energy of Li. The phase-field method simulations in this work were performed by COMSOL Multiphysics 5.2 with implemented finite element solver. The morphology evolution of Li was performed in a 200 × 200 nm half-cell. In order to mimic the experimental situation, the TiO2 half-particles with the radius of 5 nm were added on the surface of Ti3C2T x . Cyclic I-V data for Li plating was used as the input of electrostatic boundary conditions for Li plating. And Initial phase-field values were given based on the surface roughness of bare TiO2 which is also useful to reduce the computation cost for dendrite growth. In addition, the electrode surface was set as a constant lithium-ion consumption source to simulate the reaction current. 3 Results and discussion The Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode applied in Li-O2 batteries was prepared via electrochemically depositing metallic Li into the 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene scaffold (Fig. 1 a). Li deposition on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene scaffold and conventional current collector are schematically illustrated in Fig. 1b. In opposite to dendrite growth on conventional current collector without lithiophilic sites, uniform and compact Li deposition can be directed by controlling the Li nucleation behavior on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold. Serving as a reservoir, Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets with high electronic conductivity could regulate uniform diffusion of Li ions rather than dendrite growth and deposition. In addition, the highly dispersed Vo-TiO2 NPs are conducive to the uniform electric field distribution on the surface of the electrode. Moreover, with the oxygen vacancy on the surface of the Vo-TiO2 NPs, a local built-in electric field can be introduced into the NPs to bring about the high adsorption energy of Vo-TiO2 sites for Li species (vide infra). On the basis of the classical heterogeneous nucleation theory (Fig. S1), Li heterogeneous nucleation barrier ΔG het is related to the binding energy (E B) between the framework and Li [38]. Δ G het = S ( θ ) Δ G hom S ( θ ) = ( 2 + cos θ ) ( 1 - cos θ ) 2 / 4 cos θ = ( γ FE - γ LF ) / γ LE where ΔG het and ΔG hom are the heterogeneous and homogeneous nucleation barrier, respectively, γFE, γLF, and γLE are the interfacial free energy of framework/electrolyte, Li/framework and Li/electrolyte, respectively. When the binding energy between Li and the framework is increased, the surface tension of Li on the substrate and γLF is reduced. Therefore, cosθ is increased and S(θ) and ΔG het is decreased. In a word, a framework that can offer a large E B toward Li can reduce the Li nucleation barrier. Thus high E B between Vo-TiO2 sites and Li atom will endow the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold with lithiophilicity. As a result, the uniformly distributed Vo-TiO2 particles could direct the Li+ to move evenly towards the electrode surface, and the lithiophilicity can promote preferential adsorption at the same time. Therefore, early nucleation behavior of Li is effectively regulated and dendrite-free Li deposition can be realized on the 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold accordingly. X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization of the as-prepared samples is presented in Figs. 2 a and S2. Obviously, after HF etching, the diffraction peak at 39° assigning to the (104) plane disappears in comparison with the original Ti3AlC2, indicating the transformation from Ti3AlC2 to Ti3C2T x after elimination of the Al layers [39,40]. Besides, after ethanol-thermal treatment, a new peak at 25.4° assigning to the (101) face of TiO2 crystal phase appears. It is found that the titanium atoms at the edge of the layered Ti3C2T x MXene are thermodynamically metastable, which makes them function as nucleation sites to generate relatively stable TiO2 NPs during ethanol-thermal treatment process (detailed discussions are presented in Supplementary Information). Thus, the formation of heterojunction structure with TiO2 NPs growing in situ on the 2D Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets is reasonable [40]. From the Raman spectra (Fig. S3), three peaks are observed at 250, 400, and 600 cm−1, suggesting the existence of the nonstoichiometric δ-TiCx phase rather than stoichiometric δ-TiC [41]. In addition, the peak at around 150 cm−1shows the generation of the TiO2 NPs [42]. In Fig. S4, the XPS survey spectrum shows the presence of Ti, O, C, and F elements before and after ethanol-thermal treatment. The Ti 2p fine spectroscopy of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x (Fig. 2b) shows the peaks at 455.01, 455.67, 456.74, 459.84, 461.07, 462.44, and 465.53 eV, which are corresponding to the Ti–C (2p 3), Ti2+ (2p 3), Ti3+ (2p 3), TiO (2p 3), Ti2+ (2p 1), Ti–C (2p 1), and TiO (2p 1), respectively [43]. The obvious enhancement of Ti–O peak accompanying with the decease of the other peaks of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x as compared to that of Ti3C2T x MXene (Fig. S5) indicates the transformation of Ti3C2T x MXene to TiO2 upon the ethanol-thermal treatment. Notably, there are terminal functional groups such as –O, –OH and –F on both Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x and Ti3C2T x MXene (Fig. S6). Room temperature electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x rather than Ti3C2T x shows a clear signal with g = 1.998 (Fig. 2c ans S7), corroborating that a great number of oxygen vacancies were produced after the ethanol-thermal process. In Fig. S8–9, the layered Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x shows larger SSA of 47.6 m2 g−1 as compared to Ti3C2T x MXene (15.4 m2 g−1), which is mainly due to the formation of Vo-TiO2 NPs on the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets, effectively preventing the aggregation of individual layers [42]. In addition, it should be noted that conductive framework with high surface area can reduce the current density effectively and retard dendrite growth by accommodating Li deposits, thus restraining the crack of SEI during Li plating/stripping process and leading to stable cycles even under lean-electrolyte conditions [44]. The electronic conductivities of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , Ti3C2T x MXene, and TiO2 are measured by using four-probe instrument at room temperature and the results are shown in Table S1. The electronic conductivity of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x is 780 S cm−1, which is much higher than that of Ti3C2T x (40 S cm−1) and TiO2 (10 × 10−10 S cm−1). The scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of Ti3AlC2 is shown in Fig. S10, and the bulk Ti3AlC2 could be clearly observed. The morphology and structure features of Ti3C2T x and Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x prepared via ethanol-thermal treatment are shown in Fig. 2d–i. The Ti3C2T x MXene exhibits typical exfoliated 2D structure (Fig. 2d). Large amount of Vo-TiO2 NPs distribute evenly on the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets after the ethanol-thermal process (Fig. 2e). Actually, Ti3C2T x MXene is unstable and can be easily oxidized to form self-agglomerated TiO2 in air atmosphere, which greatly limits the development and application of MXene (Fig. S11). One step ethanol-thermal treatment employed here guarantees to fabricate uniform Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , which avoids the self-agglomeration of Vo-TiO2 NPs and facilitates the full exposure of the lithiophilic sites. TEM images further display the layered morphology for both Ti3C2T x and Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x samples (Fig. 2f, g). However, the surface of the latter is much rougher than that of the former because of the formation of Vo-TiO2 NPs on the Ti3C2T x nanosheets. In Fig. S12, the HRTEM image of Ti3C2T x shows clear lattice fringe with an interplanar space of 0.23 nm, which can be assigned to the (103) crystal face of Ti3C2T x MXene. The Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x shows well-resolved lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.23 and 0.35 nm (Fig. 2h), which can accurately be ascribed to the (103) crystal face of Ti3C2T x MXene and (101) crystal face of anatase TiO2, respectively. Blurred areas in the HRTRM image of Fig. 2h can be observed, which is likely due to the lattice distortion caused by Vo [45,46]. Besides, the element mapping verifies that the Ti, C, O, and F elements are dispersed homogeneously (Fig. 2i), further indicating that Vo-TiO2 NPs distribute uniformly on the Ti3C2T x nanosheets. The morphology of Li deposits on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold was then investigated. The pristine Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode shows an interconnected 3D porous architecture and these large number of pore channels can guarantee sufficient electrolyte flow and rapid transport of Li+ (Fig. S13). Notably, the desired Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes can be easily obtained by pre-depositing Li into the 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x . To investigate the nucleation morphology of Li on Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , Ti3C2T x , and Cu foil, Li deposition with a small capacity of 0.5 mAh cm−2 was conducted at the nucleation stage (Fig. S14). Homogeneous distribution of dense star-like Li nuclei is observed on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , which can be attributed to superior lithiophilicity of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , enabling Li nucleation to take place preferentially on the scaffold rather than Cu foil (Fig. S14a). However, different from that on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , the nucleation morphology on pure Ti3C2T x skeleton shows 1D rope-like structure without the seed layer, which indicates the fact that Li plating tends to aggregate to bumps, aggravating the subsequent 1D dendritic Li growth (Fig. S14b). This is because the addition of a Li adatom to an existing Li nuclei is more favorable and has a lower energy barrier than forming a stable cluster (embryo) of Li atoms. As shown in Fig. S14c, the Li particles are sparsely and unevenly distributed on the surface of Cu foil and bare Cu is visible underneath the Li. With slightly increasing the Li plating capacity to 1 mAh cm−2, Li metal still tends to deposit around lithiophilic Vo-TiO2 NPs which are uniformly distributed on the Ti3C2T x MXene scaffold (Fig. S15). With the plating capacity increasing up to 2 mAh cm−2, Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene scaffold wrapped with Li is still visible, indicating that the deposition of Li can be easily spread out (Fig. S16). While further plating Li up to 10 mAh cm−2, it can be observed clearly that metallic Li gradually grows to adjacent dense bulk structure without dendritic morphology at the top surface of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold (Fig. 3 a). As indicated in the enlarged images, the block of deposited Li with an average size of ~4 μm along the horizontal direction (Fig. 3b). This may be originated from the uniform distribution of Li ion flux on the surface of electrode because of its porous architecture, eventually leading to the even deposition of Li metal. Such a dendrite-free morphology can effectively alleviate parasitic reactions between electrolyte and Li because of the limited contact surface, thus improving the Coulombic efficiency and cycle life. Instead, dendritic Li growth obviously shoot out on the bare Cu foil only after a small deposition capacity of 3 mAh cm−2, which is much lower than that of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold (Fig. 3c, d). Similar dendritic growth phenomenon appears on the Ti3C2T x MXene with the plating capacity of up to 10 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 3e–f). In addition, the electrode thickness variation after Li deposition is revealed via cross-sectional SEM images. After Li deposition with the capacity of 10 mAh cm−2, the thickness increases from ~41 μm for Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x to ~105 μm for Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li (Figs. 3g and S17). For Cu foil, the deposited Li metal is highly loose and porous, and the thickness increases from 9 to 33 μm after depositing with capacity of 3 mAh cm−2 (Figs. 3h and S18). Analogously, when depositing Li metal on the Ti3C2T x host with the same capacity as that on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold, the remarkable electrode expansion (from 45 to 183 μm) is observed, as shown in Figs. 3i and S19. Accordingly, compared with the other two electrodes, the robust 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold is competent to withstand the volume variation caused by repeated Li plating and stripping, indicating the excellent mechanical durability of this electrode. Furthermore, by using situ optical microscopy, the surface morphologies of the Cu current collector and Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold during the Li metal deposition process are investigated via recording images at different stages. As shown in Fig. 3j–k, numerous moss-like Li appears on the Cu current collector during the 30 min plating process, which can be attributed to the lithiophobic and hostless feature of the Cu foil. In comparison, the surface of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold remains smooth and flat, eventually leading to a dendrite-free morphology upon plating process. Obviously, there is almost no volume change during the whole Li deposition process for Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold. This observation intuitively reflects that Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold can effectively suppress the Li dendrites formation by adjusting the deposition behavior of Li deposits. To explain the uniform Li nucleation and deposition behavior on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold as compared to the pristine Ti3C2T x nanosheets and TiO2, nonlinear phase-field model coupling with mass transport and charge conservation equations analysis was performed to study the evolution behavior. As shown in Fig. 4 , for the Ti3C2T x nanosheets, few Li nucleation sites can be formed at the electrode/electrolyte interface primarily because of the poor Li affinity nature of the electrode. The tips of the nucleation induce the high concentration of Li ions around it, leading to the increase of the local current density. Then Li preferentially grows on the tips, leading to the growth of Li dendrites (Fig. 4a). Fig. 4b indicates that the distribution of Li ions is inhomogeneous, resulting in the concentration of current density around dendrite tips, as shown in Fig. 4c. By contrast, consistent with the observed morphology from the experimental results in Fig. 3a, dendrite-free and dense Li can conformally deposit on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold ( Fig. 4d). As shown in Fig. 4e, Li ions distribution is homogeneous over the entire electrode surface. The highly ordered spacing between Vo-TiO2 NPs directs the Li ions to move evenly toward the electroactive surface area. As shown in Fig. 4f, the current density distributes uniformly on the electrode surface due to the homogeneously dispersed Vo-TiO2 NPs. Consequently, Li metal continuously nucleates and grows on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold evenly. However, for the pristine TiO2 electrode, Li deposits mostly at the top of nucleation sites which are abundant but irregular, causing the deposition of Li dendrites (Fig. 4g). In addition, Li ions are mainly concentrated over the top of the dendrites on the surface of TiO2 electrode, as shown in Fig. 4h. The current density profile in Fig. 4i is corresponding to the uneven surface of the deposited Li metal. During the electrode position process, sharp edges and blunt points on the electrode surface are most likely to produce strong local electric fields. These electric fields attract large quantities of Li ions, leading to the uneven distribution of local current density, and consequently nonuniform Li deposition. The disorganized Li surface together with the uneven distribution of current density leads to the fracture of the solid electrolyte interface, causing further dendrite formation and growth eventually. In contrast, electrical field strength is homogeneous at the electrode where the surface is relatively uniform. Then Li ions can evenly migrate at the interface, leading to the uniform local current density distribution, which facilitates the uniform Li deposition. Thus, the highly dispersed Vo-TiO2 NPs on Ti3C2T x framework play a critical role in regulating the uniform Li deposition on Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was further carried out to reveal the Li nucleation and deposition behavior. As shown in Fig. 5 a and b, two potential sites on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , the edge sites of Vo-TiO2 and the top sites of Vo-TiO2, were proposed to calculate the nucleation behavior of Li. The binding energies of Li atoms are −2.46 and −2.32 eV on edge sites and top sites of Vo-TiO2, respectively. Besides, the binding energies of Li atoms absorbed on the pristine Ti3C2T x and TiO2 scaffold are calculated to be −0.72 and −1.05 eV, respectively (Fig. 5c and d). The results indicate that the adsorption of Li on the Vo-TiO2 are much stronger than those on the Ti3C2T x and TiO2, corroborating the hypothesis that Vo-TiO2 surface is favorable for Li atom adsorption. In addition, it is the edge sites that are the most preferable adsorption point of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold for Li atoms. Differential charge density analysis further reveals that electron interaction on the surface of the Vo-TiO2 for both edge sites and top sites are much stronger than those on the pristine Ti3C2T x and TiO2 (Fig. 5e). This result can be further explained by analyzing the charge distribution on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold (Fig. 5f–h). Fig. S21 suggests that charge deviation arising from the oxygen vacancy of TiO2 NPs can cause the deviation of charge on the other atoms, especially those in the vicinity of the vacancy sites, leading to imbalanced charge distribution. The lopsided charge distribution intrinsically triggers a built-in electric field, which makes Li ions absorbed under an adventitious Coulombic force [46,47] (Fig. 5i). To be specific, a significant charge transfer phenomenon and unbalanced charge distributions induce a positively charged region at the oxygen vacancy and a negatively charged area near the oxygen vacancy. Particularly, at the atomic level, the local electric field that points to the negatively charged region from the non-vacancy area will provide the Coulombic force for Li ions to accelerate the migration and congregate around the vacancies. Therefore, the favorable adsorption leads to high binding energy, which contributes preferential Li nucleation and subsequent Li deposition on these Vo-TiO2 sites of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold. The electrochemical behaviors of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , Ti3C2T x , TiO2 and Cu foil electrodes were firstly investigated in symmetric coin cells. Based on classical nucleation theory, the free energy barrier of a new solid phase nucleation is associated with the thermodynamic costs of a critical cluster of atoms and it means that changing the electrochemical supersaturation of the working electrode via tuning the overpotential of the reduction reaction can effectively adjust the nucleation barrier for the electrodeposition [48]. Specifically, due to galvanostatic electrocrystallization occurring at variable supersaturation (overpotential varying with time), nucleation overpotential is chosen as the critical parameter to describe Li nucleation and growth because of its easy extractability from experiment. The representative discharge curves at the current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 were shown in Fig. 6 a. Specifically, the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode exhibits lower Li nucleation overpotential of 17 mV compared with Ti3C2T x (99 mV), TiO2 (30 mV) and Cu foil (39 mV), demonstrating its superior Li plating kinetics in consequence of the excellent lithiophilicity of Vo-TiO2 NPs on the Ti3C2T x nanolayers. After the initial nucleation stage on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold, the overpotential decreases to a flat voltage plateau, indicating that the deposition of Li atoms on the formed Li nuclei demonstrates lower energy barrier, thus leading to the facile Li deposition as compared to the initial Li nucleation. The Coulombic efficiency of the electrodes upon cycling with a Li plating capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 at 0.2 mA cm−2 was presented in Fig. 6b. The average Coulombic efficiency of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode was about 95.4% after 100 cycles, which is much better than those of pristine TiO2 after 30 cycles (87%), Ti3C2T x after 65 cycles (90.5%) and Cu after 61 cycles (80.1%). Besides, the Coulombic efficiency of the Ti3C2T x electrode rapidly drops after 65 cycles due to the irreversible loss of Li during the repeated stripping and plating processes. Accumulated irreversible capacity of Li is defined as the capacity that the battery cannot release after a certain period of charge–discharge cycle, which is mainly caused by the formation of “dead Li’’. The inactive “dead Li’’ consists of both electrochemically formed Li compounds in the solid electrolyte interphase and electrically isolated unreacted metallic Li, causing capacity loss and safety hazards. The accumulated irreversible capacity of the Ti3C2T x electrode reached 23.85 mAh cm−2 after 48 cycles, indicating more than 22 times of excess Li was consumed (Fig. 6c). Similarly, the pristine TiO2 and Cu electrodes demonstrate large irreversible capacities of 24.89 mAh cm−2 after 77 cycles and 14.12 mAh cm−2 after 61 cycles, respectively. Significantly, due to the high Coulombic efficiency of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x , much less irreversible capacity (13.87 mAh cm−2) was demonstrated after 100 cycles. As shown in Fig. S22, the cell composed of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode delivers CE of 95% over 97 cycles at current density of 1 mA cm−2, which is much higher as compared to those of TiO2 electrode after 51 cycles (83%), Ti3C2T x electrode after 50 cycles (90%) and Cu electrode after 28 cycles (85%). Furthermore, XRD patterns of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode during CE test at different stages have supplemented in Fig. S23, in which regular Li plating and stripping process within the lithiophilic Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold can be intuitively revealed. The Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li symmetric cells were assembled and tested under plating/stripping capacity of 0.1 mAh cm−2 to obtain the galvanostatic cycling performance of symmetric cells, as shown in Fig. 6d. The TiO2@Li and Cu@Li symmetric cells exhibit abruptly increased hysteresis values, indicating that potential short circuits caused by dendrite penetration may exist here. Additionally, the voltage hysteresis of Ti3C2T x @Li anode gradually increases in 600 h, suggesting the sluggish kinetics of Li plating/stripping on Ti3C2T x and the gradually increased impedance caused by the repeatedly fracture/formation of SEI. On the contrary, the voltage polarization of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode maintains a particularly low value of 19 mV over 750 h, which is much lower than those of Cu@Li (over 50 mV after 130 h), TiO2@Li (over 100 mV after 144 h) and Ti3C2T x @Li (over 40 mV after 400 h), confirming the excellent Li plating and stripping behavior on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes. The exact zoomed-in voltage profiles of Ti3C2T x @Li and Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrodes in Fig. S24 are provided to exclude a possible short-circuit of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrode after hundreds of cycles in Fig. 6d. As shown in Fig. S24a, the zoomed-in profile of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrode from 598 to 600 h without a short-circuit phenomenon exhibits a decrease in operation voltage as compared to that of the Ti3C2T x @Li electrode, indicative of fast kinetics of Li plating/stripping on Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x and low impedance attributed to the stable SEI. The zoomed-in profile from 748 to 750 h was also analyzed (Fig. S24b) and the short-circuit phenomenon cannot be observed, demonstrating its superior Li plating/stripping kinetics in consequence of the excellent lithiophilicity of Vo-TiO2 NPs on the Ti3C2T x nanolayers. Voltage profiles of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li symmetric cells are obtained at 1 mA cm−2 with a Li plating/stripping capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. The symmetric cell with Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrode exhibits low overpotential and superior long-term cycling performance (over 600 h) as compared to those with Ti3C2T x @Li (~470 h), TiO2@Li (~180 h) and Cu@Li (~50 h) (Fig. S25). Voltage profiles of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li based symmetric cells at 3 mA cm−2 with a Li plating/stripping capacity of 3 mAh cm−2 and 5 mA cm−2 with a Li plating/stripping capacity of 5 mAh cm−2 are provided in Fig. S 26 and 27, respectively. The symmetric cells with Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrodes exhibit not only low overpotentials but also superior long-term cycling performances as compared to those with Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li. The possible reason could be attributed to uniform distribution of Li nuclei followed by flat Li growth realized on the scaffold. The comparison of rate performance between Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li, Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li symmetrical cells is shown in Fig. 6e. The Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li symmetrical cells shows low voltage hysteresis of 8, 22, 35, 58, and 94 mV at 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.5 mA cm−2, respectively. In addition, the stable polarization value can be observed during cycling at each current density for Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li based cell, which can be ascribed to the formation of stable SEI. On the contrary, the Ti3C2T x @Li, TiO2@Li and Cu@Li electrodes all present larger voltage hysteresis than that of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrode at each set of current density and fluctuant curves at high current density (0.5 mA cm−2), which can be attributed to the large kinetic barrier of Li plating and stripping for those electrodes, giving rise to severe dendrite growth [49,50]. The rapid Li+ transport is believed to be another possible reason for the improved rate capability [51]. To confirm this, contact angle test was carried out, as shown in Fig. 6f. The contact angle of electrolyte on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode is 8.151°, which is smaller than those on Ti3C2T x (16.827°), pristine TiO2 (17.050°), and Cu (18.616°) electrode, suggesting that Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode has excellent affinity with ether-based electrolyte. Thus, the capillary force provided by the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x surface is capable of improving the wettability of electrode. With the penetration of electrolyte into the channels and submicron level pores inside Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode, this improved wettability can decrease the Li+ transport distance. In addition, the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode can enhance the uptake capacity of electrolyte because of its high electrolyte affinity and accessibility, which is favorable for homogenizing Li+ distribution in the vicinity of electrodes. According to the above results, it can be deduced that the improved electrochemical performance of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode will greatly reduce the required amount of excess Li loaded on the electrode, thus improving the overall energy density and Li utilization efficiency. To demonstrate this, bare Cu foils with Li reservoir of 2 mAh cm−2 as well as 4 mAh cm−2 were compared with Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode with Li reservoir of 2 mAh cm−2. It can be seen from Fig. 6g that the excess amount of Li would increase by a factor of more than two for Cu foil in order to obtain a comparable cycle life with the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold. To explore the electrochemical performances under lean electrolyte conditions, different amounts of electrolyte ranging from 5 to 30 μL were loaded in Li/Cu half cells, and the cells were discharged/charged at 1 mA cm−2 with an areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S28a). The Li plating and stripping are stable at the electrolyte loading of 10, 20, and 30 μL. While decreasing the electrolyte loading to 5 μL, the cell cannot keep stable charge behavior, which is mainly due to the insufficient wetting of the electrode by electrolyte. Hence, 10 μL is chosen as the minimum amount of the electrolyte, which is similar to the previous work [44]. Then, cells are cycled at the current density of 1 mA cm−2 with an areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 by using 10 μL electrolyte (Fig. S28b). As expected, the CE of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x host remains stable during cycling (95.2%). However, the CE of Cu foil host degrades to 75% after tens of cycles. Besides, the CE of Ti3C2T x and Vo-TiO2 become fluctuant and dramatically decrease after 40 cycles. Then symmetric cells are assembled to conduct the long-time galvanostatic cycling. As shown in Fig. S22c, Cu@Li cell shows abruptly increased hysteresis only after 33 h, indicating its poor cycling stability. TiO2@Li and Ti3C2T x @Li symmetric cells present larger voltage hysteresis (68 and 63 mV, respectively) as compared to Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x cell (45 mV) after 100 h, which is possibly due to the polarization caused by dendrite formation and breaking down of the SEI layer. To explore its potential applications, the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 battery with Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode is then evaluated under the cut-off capacity of 1000 mAh g−1. Besides, Li-O2 battery with conventional Li foil with excess Li is also studied for comparison. Fig. S29 and Fig. 7 a show the discharge–charge curves and the evolution of the terminal voltage of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x based Li-O2 battery. Surprisingly, with most of the discharge platforms overlapped, Li-O2 battery based on the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode shows extended cycling performances of nearly 100 cycles, which is the longest cycle life among metallic lithium based Li-O2 batteries as listed in Fig. 7b [6,15,50,52]. On the contrary, Li-O2 batteries based on conventional Li foil anode fail after 26 cycles with the increased charge platforms and ill-defined discharge plateaus (Fig. S30). Such improved cycling performances indicate the high utilization of Li in Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode profiting from the stable SEI and highly reversible plating/stripping process. The Li-O2 batteries based on Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode also exhibit good rate capability (Fig. 7c), which can be attributed to the facile ion/electron transport and the uniform Li nucleation on the electrode. The greatly reduced polarization and improved durability is further supported by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis before and after cycling (Fig. 7d). The corresponding equivalent circuit has been shown in Fig. S31. The bare Li foils show an extremely large interfacial resistance of 165 Ω before cycling, which originates from the native oxygen layers formed on the electrode surface. After 26 cycles, interfacial resistance drops to a much lower value of 93 Ω due to the collapse of the native oxide layers and the increased surface area caused by dendrite formation. In contrast, the 3D Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode demonstrates constantly low interfacial resistance of 75 and 58 Ω both before and after cycling, respectively. This phenomenon suggests that improved electrode stability and more favorable Li plating/stripping kinetics can be achieved with 3D porous Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li electrode. To demonstrate the protection of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold from the growth of Li dendrite, the battery after 20 cycles was disassembled to investigate the structure of the composite Li anode. As exhibited in Fig. 7e, f, the cycled Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li composite anode still has a smooth and flat surface without any detected Li dendrite and LiOH patterns, confirming the protection effect of the designed Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold for Li deposition. While for the conventional Li foil anode, it exhibits uneven surface morphology with obvious corrosion (Fig. 7g). The above results support the high utilization of metallic Li in Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode based Li-O2 battery, which far exceeds that based on commercial Li foil. Furthermore, due to the high requirements for flexible electronic devices, the superior electrochemical performance of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li composite anode inspires us to further explore its application under practical conditions. Flexible Li-O2 battery using Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode is thus assembled and studied. Configurated with the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode, the digital photograph of typically assembled Li-O2 battery is shown in Fig. 7h, demonstrating an open-circuit voltage of 2.93 V0. Besides, a “CDUT” light emitting diode (LED) panel could be lighted by the flexible Li-O2 battery with Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li composite anode (Fig. 7i). The excellent electrochemical performance of both coin-type Li-O2 battery and pouch-type flexible Li-O2 battery not only reveals the effectiveness of Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li composite anode for suppressing Li dendrites during cycling, but also demonstrates the applicability of this composite anode on practical Li metal batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile strategy enabling homogeneous Li nuclei distribution and dendrite-free Li deposition is proposed by constructing orderly lithiophilic Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold, in which Vo-TiO2 NPs distribute evenly on 3D conductive Ti3C2T x MXene skeleton. According to DFT calculations and COMSOL multiphysics simulation, the strong interaction between lithium and oxygen vacancy on TiO2 NPs guides uniform Li+ flux over the surface of the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x electrode, leading to uniform Li nucleation and deposition. The designed lithiophilic Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x scaffold are beneficial to realizing homogeneous Li deposition even with a high Li reservoir of 10 mA h cm−2 due to the significantly reduced local current density and alleviated volume fluctuation. Consequently, compared with the Ti3C2T x @Li and TiO2@Li counterparts, Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes exhibit much lower voltage hysteresis and extended long-term stability (with a voltage hysteresis of only ~17 mV over 750 h). A stable CE of 95.4% is also achieved after 100 cycles at the current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 with an areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. Moreover, the prolonged cyclability and improved rate performance of Vo-Ti3C2T x @Li based Li-O2 battery confirm the high Li utilization of Vo-Ti3C2T x @Li electrode. This work shines new light on designing and constructing advanced Li metal anodes for next generation Li metal based batteries. coredata.dc:description: Uncontrollable Li dendrite growth and infinite volume fluctuation during durative plating and stripping process gravely hinder the application of metallic Li electrode in lithium-oxygen batteries. Herein, oxygen vacancy-rich TiO2 (Vo-TiO2) nanoparticles (NPs) uniformly dispersing on Ti3C2T x (Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x ) with excellent lithiophilicity feature are presented as effective composite anodes, on which a dense and uniform Li growth behavior is observed. Based on electrochemical studies, mutiphysics simulation and theoretical calculation, it is found that Vo-TiO2 coupling with three dimensional (3D) conductive Ti3C2T x MXene forms highly ordered lithiophilic sites which succeed in guiding Li ions flux and adsorption, thus modulating the uniform Li nucleation and growth. As a result, this composite electrode is capable of preserving Li with high areal capacity of ~10 mAh cm−2 without the presence of dendrites and large volume expansion. Consequently, the as-prepared Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anode shows outstanding performance including low voltage hysteresis (~19 mV) and superior durability (over 750 h). When assembling with the Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x @Li anodes, lithium-oxygen batteries also deliver enhanced cycling stability and improved rate performance. This work demonstrates the effectiveness of oxygen vacancies in guiding Li nucleating and plating behavior at initial stage and brings a promising strategy for promoting the development of advanced Li metal-based batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Long-cycling lithium-oxygen batteries enabled by tailoring Li nucleation and deposition via lithiophilic oxygen vacancy in Vo-TiO2/Ti3C2T x composite anodes
